extracted_data.point: [RISK] Aspiration of gastric contents into the lungs can lead to pneumonia, respiratory failure, and permanent lung damage. Risk is higher in fasting patients.
[RISK] Laryngospasm during intubation or mask placement can cause airway obstruction; requires medication, occasionally intensive care.
[RISK] Prolonged or severe drowsiness, confusion, or cognitive impairment may occur, especially in older patients, and can last several days to months.
[RISK] Malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic gases or muscle relaxants, is extremely rare but requires intensive treatment.
[RISK] Inadvertent intravenous injection of local anesthetic can lead to systemic toxicity, causing seizures, cardiovascular collapse, or death.
[RISK] Pneumothorax due to needle puncture of the pleura (especially in thoracic PDA or arm plexus) can cause breathing difficulties and requires chest tube insertion.
[RISK] Spinal or epidural anesthesia may cause permanent paralysis (e.g., urinary retention, incontinence), rare but potentially life-altering.
[RISK] Post-procedure catheter placement may lead to catheter kinking, vessel or nerve damage, requiring surgical removal or intervention.

[INSTRUCTION] Adults may consume a light, easily digestible meal up to 6 hours before anesthesia; otherwise, only clear fluids (1–2 glasses) are allowed 6–2 hours prior, with no fat, solids, or alcohol.
[INSTRUCTION] Patients under 18 must fast for up to 6 hours and consume only clear fluids (no fat, solids, alcohol) for 6 to 1 hour prior to anesthesia.
[INSTRUCTION] Smoking increases anesthesia and surgical risks, including respiratory complications and cardiovascular events.
[INSTRUCTION] Do not get up alone after anesthesia; remain under supervision until vital functions stabilize to prevent falls and injuries.
[INSTRUCTION] Do not drive, operate machinery, consume alcohol, or perform hazardous activities for at least 24 hours or as directed by the doctor.
[INSTRUCTION] Do not take medications without explicit doctor approval after anesthesia.
[PREREQUISITE] A central venous catheter may be placed prior to anesthesia for medication administration and monitoring.
[PREREQUISITE] A regional catheter may be placed preoperatively for pain management and can be used for both anesthesia and postoperative analgesia.
[GENERAL_INFO] General anesthesia involves inducing unconsciousness and pain insensitivity throughout the body; regional anesthesia blocks pain in a specific body region.
[GENERAL_INFO] Intubation or laryngeal mask may be used for ventilation during anesthesia to prevent aspiration and ensure adequate oxygenation.
[GENERAL_INFO] Arm plexus block targets nerves in the arm and is used for shoulder, arm, or hand procedures.
[GENERAL_INFO] Spinal and epidural anesthesia block nerves in the lower body and are used for lower body surgeries.
[GENERAL_INFO] Women using hormonal contraceptives may experience reduced effectiveness for at least 7 days after anesthesia.
